docs.lead_paragraph: Paying attention may be overrated. Researchers have found evidence that people learn some things without trying and, in fact, without even being aware that they are paying attention. Scientists came to this conclusion after exposing volunteers to subliminal information -- images they were not consciously aware of -- and then seeing if the images had any effect. The findings were presented in last week's issue of Nature.
docs.abstract: Researchers report volunteers exposed to subliminal information, images they were not consciously aware of, became better at discerning increase in pattern of such images than they had been before subconscious training; see findings challenging belief that we can escape effects of being bombarded by unimportant information by consciously ignoring data; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Paying attention may be overrated. Researchers have found evidence that people learn some things without trying and, in fact, without even being aware that they are paying attention.    Scientists came to this conclusion after exposing volunteers to...

docs.lead_paragraph: There has long been a disturbing paradox associated with being a good driver. To know how to respond to a host of difficult and often unpredictable traffic situations and hazardous road conditions, a driver needs experience behind the wheel. But in getting such experience, many new drivers, especially teenagers, end up having accidents that in all likelihood could have been avoided -- if they had had more experience.

headline.main: Reducing the Risks for Teenage Drivers

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on reducing high crash risk for inexperienced teenage drivers; cites success of graduated licensing systems adopted by many states, which phase in full driving privileges for teenagers over two or more years, in reducing accidents, injuries and deaths; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: There has long been a disturbing paradox associated with being a good driver. To know how to respond to a host of difficult and often unpredictable traffic situations and hazardous road conditions, a driver needs experience behind the wheel.    But...

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a widespread trend by government officials to require hospitals to test newborns for hearing problems, little evidence exists that detecting deafness at such an early age helps with the child's later language skills, a new study argues. About 30 states now require the so-called universal screening, prompted in part by research suggesting that the earlier a hearing problem is identified, the greater the odds that children get help that will enable them to talk and understand speech.

headline.main: Gains From Hearing Tests Are Disputed

docs.abstract: New study finds little evidence that detecting deafness in newborns helps with child's later language skills; calls into question value of requirement in 30 states that hospitals test newborns for hearing problems (M)
docs.snippet: Despite a widespread trend by government officials to require hospitals to test newborns for hearing problems, little evidence exists that detecting deafness at such an early age helps with the child's later language skills, a new study argues.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: A new device developed by government scientists to detect microscopic bits of manure on beef carcasses, a major cause of food poisoning, could soon make meat safer. The device shines a light on sides of beef, then picks up the glow from tiny amounts of the plant material chlorophyll, which is found in manure. The United States Department of Agriculture has licensed the technology to a company that will soon install test units in several slaughterhouses.

headline.main: Device May Make Beef Safer From E. Coli

docs.abstract: Agriculture Department has licensed to eMerge Interactive device developed by government scientists to detect microscopic bits of manure, major cause of food poisoning, on beef carcasses; eMerge will soon install test units in several slaughterhouses (M)
docs.snippet: A new device developed by government scientists to detect microscopic bits of manure on beef carcasses, a major cause of food poisoning, could soon make meat safer.    The device shines a light on sides of beef, then picks up the glow from tiny...

docs.lead_paragraph: While one division of Bayer A.G. has been negotiating with the American government over the price of Cipro, used to treat and prevent anthrax in people, another branch of the company has been locked in a conflict with the government over a sister drug used to treat other infections in animals. Cipro's sister drug for animals is called Baytril; chemically, the two are very similar. The Food and Drug Administration, doctors, consumer groups and a recent editorial in The New England Journal of Medicine have all urged that Baytril be removed from the market on the grounds that its use in animals may eventually compromise the power of Cipro and similar antibiotics to fight disease in humans.

headline.main: Drug for Poultry Stirs Resistance Concerns

docs.abstract: Bayer AG division is locked in conflict with government over Baytril, drug chemically very similar to Cipro, antibiotic used to treat and prevent anthrax in humans; at issue is whether widespread use of Baytril to treat infections in poultry causes disease germs to become resistant to Cipro and other fluoroquinolones used to treat human diseases; Food and Drug Administration, doctors, consumer groups and New England Journal of Medicine want Baytril removed from market, move opposed by Bayer and poultry industry (M)
docs.snippet: While one division of Bayer A.G. has been negotiating with the American government over the price of Cipro, used to treat and prevent anthrax in people, another branch of the company has been locked in a conflict with the government over a sister...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. David Costill, a professor of exercise science at Ball State University here, has an unexpected conflict. An important donor has suddenly shown up and Dr. Costill and his colleagues must spend an hour with him. But in the meantime, a reporter has also arrived, to interview Dr. Costill. So he asks the reporter how she would like to occupy herself for an hour or so. Professors at other departments might offer a cup of coffee or a stack of journal articles to read. But this is the Human Performance Laboratory, and so the suggestions are a bit different. Run? Swim? Lift weights? When she says she would like to run, several strapping graduate students quickly ask how far and describe the best routes.

headline.main: SCIENTIST AT WORK/David Costill; A Career Spent in Study of Training And Exercise, Lap by Grueling Lap

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr David Costill, pioneer in applying scientific methods to study of exercise and training; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. David Costill, a professor of exercise science at Ball State University here, has an unexpected conflict.  An important donor has suddenly shown up and Dr. Costill and his colleagues must spend an hour with him. But in the meantime, a reporter...

docs.lead_paragraph: Stress, long thought to play a role in many diseases, appears to be an ally of the AIDS virus in its attack on the immune system, researchers said this week. Writing in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers from the University of California at Los Angeles said it appeared that the virus multiplied more quickly in people who handled stress poorly.

headline.main: Measure of Calm May Help Fight AIDS

docs.abstract: University of California at Los Angeles researchers report AIDS virus seems to multiply more quickly in people who handle stress poorly; find hormone norepinephrine, released when person is under stress, may help HIV bind more easily to cells and spur it to replicate more freely (S)
docs.snippet: Stress, long thought to play a role in many diseases, appears to be an ally of the AIDS virus in its attack on the immune system, researchers said this week.    Writing in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers from the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever run a marathon can testify to the toll it can take on the body, from painful shin splints to disabling stress fractures. A new study suggests that long-distance running may put stresses on the body that are less obvious but potentially more dangerous. Writing in The American Journal of Cardiology, researchers say they have found evidence of temporary changes in blood chemistry in marathoners that could increase their risk of heart attack.

headline.main: The Pain of the Long-Distance Runner

docs.abstract: Researchers report finding evidence of temporary changes in blood chemistry of marathon runners 24 hours after race that could increase their risk of heart attack; cite increase in blood factors that cause clotting and inflammation and changes that could mislead doctor into thinking runner had had heart attack; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Anyone who has ever run a marathon can testify to the toll it can take on the body, from painful shin splints to disabling stress fractures.    A new study suggests that long-distance running may put stresses on the body that are less obvious but...

docs.lead_paragraph: The human form of mad cow disease may peak at 100 cases per year in Britain and kill no more than a few thousand people in coming decades, according to new estimates from a highly respected group of epidemiologists in London. But other leading experts who study the disease say that these numbers are based on overly optimistic assumptions. They say more than 100,000 people may die from the disease in the next several decades.

headline.main: Estimates of Future Human Death Toll From Mad Cow Disease Vary Widely

docs.abstract: Dr Jerome Huillard d'Aignaux and colleagues estimate mad cow disease may peak at 100 cases per year in Britain and kill no more than few thousand people in coming decades, article in journal Science; other experts say numbers are based on overly optimistic assumptions; estimate over 100,000 people may die from disease, caused by eating meat from infected cattle, in next few decades; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The human form of mad cow disease may peak at 100 cases per year in Britain and kill no more than a few thousand people in coming decades, according to new estimates from a highly respected group of epidemiologists in London.    But other leading...

docs.lead_paragraph: He says they dined on fried chicken; she says it was baked. She says it was 2 percent milk; he says 1 percent. She says he ate popcorn; he professes no recollection of it. Writing in a recent Journal of the American Dietetic Association, nutrition researchers who surveyed the eating habits of couples said they found repeated instances of disagreement between partners asked to describe what they had eaten in the last 24 hours.

headline.main: He Ate, She Ate; He Said, She Said

docs.abstract: Nutrition researchers who surveyed eating habits of couples report finding repeated instances of disagreement between partners asked to describe what they had eaten in last 24 hours; say most of men had little idea how food was prepared and failed to mention their snacks; drawing (M)
